comment.author: 7471115@N08
comment._content: That's the German luxury liner Imperator, of the Hamburg America Line, circa 1913. Note the eagle on the bow, which was later removed after the wings were ripped off in storm. After WWI, she was taken by the UK and became Cunard's Berengaria.

comment.author: 24246413@N00
comment._content:
The Latin word Imperator was a title originally roughly equivalent to commander during the period of the Roman Republic. It later went on to become a part of the titulature of the Roman Emperors as part of their cognomen.

It's so easy to look shit up, fool.

comment.author: 82036340@N00
comment._content: "SS Imperator was an ocean liner built for the Hamburg America Line (German: Hamburg-Amerikanische Packetfahrt-Actien-Gesellschaft or HAPAG) launched in 1912. She was the first of a trio of successively larger Hamburg America ships that included SS Vaterland and SS Bismarck built by the line for transatlantic passenger service. At the time of her launch in May 1912, she was the largest passenger ship in the world superseding the sunken RMS Titanic. During World War I, the ship remained in port in Hamburg. After the war she was briefly commissioned into the United States Navy as USS Imperator (ID-4080) and employed for returning American troops from Europe. Following her U.S. Navy service, Imperator was handed over to Britain's Cunard Line as part of war reparations, and she sailed as the flagship RMS Berengaria for the final decade of her career."" An excerpt from Wikipedia en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SS_Imperator I also note that she had a fire in 1913. F scott Fitzgerald set his "The Beautiful and the Dammed" aboard the RMS Berengaria, The Imperator's rechristened name after the war.

comment.author: 77975599@N03
comment._content: After the Titanic disaster of 4/12, I only see 18 life boats for a ship that size.  Apparently, the additional life boat law hadn't gone into affect at the time of this photo in 1912.

comment.author: 21686909@N07
comment._content: Jonboy, are you saying there was some sort of international maritime law about lifeboats?

comment.author: 29079609@N02
comment._content: there were regulations before but no international agreement. Recommendations were incorporated into the International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea passed in 1914.

comment.author: 21686909@N07

comment.author: 50270566@N07
comment._content: The ship had single terminal DC wiring with the steel hull being the return circuit or ground.  In the '30s there were many fires on board when hot wires grounded out from insulation failure.

My grandfather sailed on its maiden voyage.  I still have the bronze medallion given
to all 1st  Clsss passengers in the original velvet box.  I would presume these medals are fairly rare.
